comments.commentBody:
True for modern Angus, but there are other breeds that finish better on grass. Flavor is a relative thing and people may grow to like the stronger flavor of grass-fed beef.

Yes, it takes longer for a steer to reach market weight, but right now the price premium can make for a successful operation. The big problem is mid-sized abattoirs in cattle-ranching regions which are often far from the big consumer markets.

Children probably all want and certainly can use the balance two adults. None of us had a choice about being brought into conscious existence and few of us consider how our progeny might feel about entering an often unwelcoming world Unfortunately rational thought, like consideration, is in short supply.
@David Underwood:  Most of what you say is true enough, but I would not exclude hate as another ingredient.  You could call it contempt, but I'm not sure there's much difference in this case.

The Buddha said it best,  when asked by a man worried about his own pending death.   He advised the man to not worry about what may happen in an afterlife or to have concern about reincarnation, but rather to live simply in the present moment, peacefully with goodness in his heart, not striving.

And which law is that? From mediamatters:

There's not any blanket prohibition on any federal employee from using a personal email account to conduct government business," said Potomac Law Group partner Neil Koslowe, a former Justice Department special litigation counsel who has worked on cases involving the Federal Records Act.

and

Following that hearing, according to a statement from the archives, Congress amended the Federal Records Act and the Presidential Records Act in November 2014 -- 21 months after Clinton left government -- to "prohibit the use of private email accounts by government officials unless they copy or forward any such emails into their government account within 20 days." [The National Law Journal, 3/9/15]

So there was no law against gov't employees using private emails (without forwarding them) until after Clinton left office. Maybe you feel yourself obliged to follow laws that will not be enacted until sometime in the future - but most of us do not have crystal balls enabling us to find out not only what the law is, but what it will be.

http://mediamatters.org/research/2015/03/09/medias-baseless-speculation-...

No I can't tell you, neither can anyone else.  She deleted 30K emails that she deemed unimportant.  You really and truly trust her at her word?  She said she didn't do anything wrong, that she deleted emails she deemed unimportant and she refused to turn over her server.  That is a perfectly reasonable stance for you?  Would you accept that from any politician?  Their word is all you need?  Get real.

She deleted 30k emails that she says were unimportant.  You actually accept that as the truth?  Would accept the word of any other politician who claimed they already deleted the emails we don't need to see?

Her excuses concerning her emails are pathetic.  She set up the private email server precisely so she could control the information released to the public.  She did not want anyone at the State Department reviewing her email until she had sanitized it.  That way she could avoid bona fide releases of her emails and leaks as well.  Watch the litigation that has started.  If the State Department lawyers failed to issue a litigation hold to Ms. Clinton when they received subpoenas for her emails, then they--and Clinton--will be in deep trouble with the Courts.  Now, she will have to preserve the server until the courts sort out whether a forensic analysis is reasonable.

I worked for 30 years as a social worker.  Single parents have my highest respect, but they have incredible stress on them because they don't have a partner to help with child-rearing and to earn an income.  I have worked with wonderful single parents, but their children often suffered from the lack of a father in the home.  Being a single parent, having no father in the picture,  AND poverty, are all significant factors.  There is extensive research to support this.

Pointing fingers at those who end up in the hot seat of head of household is a cheap shot
---------------------
It's called Accountability, a novel notion. And there are far worse things than a cheap shot, like your son on a slab at the morgue from gun shots.
Choose one: "point fingers," or point guns, shoot, and hear more weeks of "Hands Up! Don't Shoot!" Guess what? Many of the single parents will thank you for showing their teens the consequences of irresponsibility.

Blue.
This column is not, as you say, 'beneath' it's author.

Rather, as he points out, it is an unassailable fact though an unpopular to articulate truth.
In a world where jobs are scarce and wages for the under-educated are low, so low in fact that many full time workers qualify for government assistance, there is simply no excuse for teen-age pregnancy and all the predictable life altering changes that come with it. That is true whether you are white, Black, Hispanic or anything in between.
If one does not have or expect to have the time and resources to raise a chid it is simply irresponsible to do so.

It's not single parent households, it's growing poverty in households of all categories that is the problem.  Poverty seems to be an equal opportunity crisis in African-American, hispanic and white problem and increasing.  Pointing fingers at those who end up in the hot seat of head of household is a cheap shot, a too easy answer to the much larger and intractable problem of inequality pitting the wealthy and more powerful against the poor and disenfranchised.  This column is beneath you.

Finding purpose and dedication beyond the current military/political restraints of the current military force of America is inspiring. These men who place themselves in harms way to protect 3rd world Arabs is up there with Lawrence of Arabia!!!!
The article says "that's the plan." I would suggest that "that's the problem."

I guess Obama's just being 75% neo-con has not settled well with those who will not be denied.  Hillary is warranted and guaranteed to be closer to the 100% neo-con rating that is the new standard among the group that selects.

The Democratic party is hollowed out according to the article.  I think the Democrats will lose Harry Reid's seat here in Nevada in 2016.  Hillary controls all the money and she doesn't like to share.

I do not believe she will win especially after her brief news conference explaining her use of a private email account for government business.

Putting her forward as a presidential candidate will be a mistake and the democrats will lose the presidency to the republicans to satisfy her vanity.

I just finished season three of a House of Cards. I'd say that Frank and Claire Underwood are a more charming (but equally corrupt and power-crazed) version of the Clintons.

By the time November, 2016 rolls around, many more people will say they don't want a person with Hillary Clinton's character as president.
What an awesome question for the former Nixon prosecution lawyer, and one she should be forced to answer.  However, to quote another famous New Yorker, "Nobody tells the WHOLE truth."

That's great, martin. You sound all fired up. Enjoy the trip.

PS. I don't know where you get all your energy after your blowout wedding escapade.
a suggestion: we roll up our sleeves and clean up the winter mess we've made.
Actually, that's LOS TARTS, or Mexican DIGS.
You speak well, and we need Hillary to keep the presidency because of the way that the democrats have acted in the past. No more scalito's
The reason they did what they did is that thought Obama's policies were unpopular.   How do you know they weren't right about this?
ebmem - You don't actually read the news do you?  You might want to start.  Try beginning with some financial news.

"Down the ticket, the party’s problems are worse. The two midterm elections since President Obama’s 2008 victory have wiped out an entire generation of Democratic state officeholders, costing the Democrats more than 900 state legislative seats and 11 governorships, according to an internal Democratic National Committee assessment released last month."

Imagine if the Democrats hadn't spent both of those election cycles running away from their President and their accomplishments. Imagine if the Democrats had framed the debate on their own terms rather than ceding it to the far right oligarchs, their "news" networks, and their stooges in the Tea Party then playing defense against themselves.

Hillary will save the Democrats?

Maybe they'd better figure out how to save themselves.
He did.  He was born in Duluth, but grew up in Hibbing. Hard to believe no one corrected this . . .

a great writer at the height of his powers. his craft alone is breathtaking.

it might have been orwell who explained, the most difficult task of the writer is putting down what is right in front of his nose. KOK seems particularly devoted to that principle.

oh and viz. the cigarette butts, he can also be adjudged to have tossed pearls before swine.

If you never get out of the car, you will never discover anything.

And if you never stop smoking you will never smell or experience anything.

And if you go through life drunk, you will never think of anything.

====

THREE VALUABLE LESSONS from Mr Knausgaard

I grew up in Wisconsin and Minnesota, and have enjoyed my share of Northern winters, and traveled the length of Norway. I don't think this is about the U.S., or Midwestern winters.  I'm disappointed in the comments by people who expect the author to have exactly the same perceptions and prejudices that they have, to reinforce their own beliefs about whatever it is they think the author is (or should be) describing.  I enjoyed the article, and look forward to the next chapter.

A bull's eye — you threw your darts straight at it, its banality and its brilliance.

This is oddly reminiscent of Jean Baudrillard's "AMERICA" but quite different from it. Baudrillard's language is stylistic and so are his judgments aimed at a particular reader with academic undertones, "America is the primitive culture of the future."

Far from such predictions, Karl Ove Knausgaard describes what he senses with ordinary language and without pretension refracts the unfiltered light though his vision back at us "intensifying and densifying the world" — its artificial noise, its natural silence.

Oddly enough, but precisely to your point, immediately below your comment, someone demands more for the money: the same ghastly hyperbole and entertainment that stupefies America — no longer 'primitive' but mad produced and mass consumed at the trough.

During the editorship of Anatole Broyard, in the 1980's, the NY Times Book Review was at its zenith, consistently every Sunday. It has sporadically, if ever, risen to that orbit again. But recently the NY Times Magazine has commissioned a number of long format essays that are penetrating, precise and luminous, this is one of them — the brief passage of a comet, or asteroid, over America.
Win Win!

Yes, I'm having the same reaction.  Talk about double speak!  I love that the Dalai Lama is threatening the Chinese with just plain old refusing to reincarnate--the analogy to Castro picking the next pope is priceless!

Excuse me if I am just a 'westerner' who does not understand but I can't stop laughing.  The Chinese Government controls reincarnation?  Wow.  Very impressive.  Enlightened bureaucrats perhaps?  Are there uniforms involved?  Badges and certificates of promotion?  They apparently can travel between both worlds, see the unseen while also allowing uniform existence here on Earth?  Validate parking too? Very impressive.  I understand it's all political and controlling but wow, if there is a more ludicrous statement ever made I have yet to hear it.  That's hilarious.

Dalai Lama himself in his earlier lives agreed to have Beijing confirm his reincarnation to ensure national unity as many believers live outside the administrative region under Lhasa. #14 is renegading a promise he made.

@AmateurHistorian - "Dalai Lama himself in his earlier lives agreed to have Beijing confirm his reincarnation to ensure national unity as many believers live outside the administrative region under Lhasa"

Really? And you know this, how?

"Decision-making power over the reincarnation of the Dalai Lama, and over the end or survival of this lineage, resides in the central government of China,” said Mr. Zhu"

That line explains everything... this is a control issue. It's common knowledge that the CCP micromanages China, down to the last detail... from which websites Chinese people can visit to what they can post on Twitter or the locally approved equivalent, from what "art" means to how religion is to be practiced, if at all. Right now it is only the "minorities" in Tibet who are in the news. But what of the voiceless millions in the mainland who are simply disappeared for crossing some arbitrary line set by the CCP? The Tibetans in Tibet and those in exile in India have made their situation visible - we haven't done much to help.
He has a choice.
Why is it not right for the media to challange Hillary and quite alright for any Republican to be challenged and bashed? Do you think perhaps their is media bias? I think so.

Patrick Healy may very well be correct here, but it is sad to think the media people have decided their mission is no longer to report the news but to create the news.

Whether he is correct or not, the media's adoption of the role of opponent to Mrs. Clinton gives me the shivers. I guess I expect more from a press whose freedom our Founders thought so critical to our well-being that they protected it in the First Amendment.

Thomas Jefferson famously said, "If I had to choose between government without newspapers, and newspapers without government, I wouldn't hesitate to choose the latter."

But what happens when that same press, whose freedom is so protected, decides to take on the role of one of the jousting political Parties?

When I read or listen to respected news providers, I expect to see or hear news that has been carefully checked and rechecked for accuracy and completeness.

After all, if we were to read (for example) "many American soldiers killed many Germans between 1941 and 1945," without pointing out that World War II was going one, would we think of that sort of reporting as journalism?

I think not.

No, it is not all right for the media to take on an adversarial role with regard to Mrs. Clinton.

The media people need to get back to doing their journalistic job, which is reporting the news with ALL the known relevant facts, not the just cherry-picked facts.

Hillary Clinton doesn't like or trust the news media. Too bad. We need a free press to keep an eye on government and to speak truth to power - including Mrs. Clinton.

Disgracefully, the 2015 WorldPress Freedom Index rates the U.S. under the current administration 49th in the world. There is a real possibility that the rating would fall even lower under a President Hillary Clinton and her penchant for secrecy and control.
